qas.question: What year was the discovery of hydrogen gas?
Who recognized hydrogen gas as a discreet substance?
In what year did Henry Cavendish recognize hydrogen gas as a discreet substance?
What does gas produce when burned?

context: In <a0_0>1671<a0_0/>, <a1_0>Robert Boyle<a1_0/> discovered and described the reaction between iron filings and dilute acids, which results in the production of hydrogen gas. In <a3_0>1766<a3_0/>, <a2_0>Henry Cavendish<a2_0/> was the first to recognize hydrogen gas as a discrete substance, by naming the gas from a metal-acid reaction "flammable air". He speculated that "flammable air" was in fact identical to the hypothetical substance called "phlogiston" and further finding in 1781 that the gas produces <a4_0>water<a4_0/> when burned. He is usually given credit for its discovery as an element. In 1783, Antoine Lavoisier gave the element the name hydrogen (from the Greek ὑδρο- hydro meaning "water" and -γενής genes meaning "creator") when he and Laplace reproduced Cavendish's finding that water is produced when hydrogen is burned.
